title: World's first island beach club is the stuff of dreams - and surprisingly cheap
text:

A luxury beach club on a sun-soaked private island sounds like something reserved for the A-list, but a new hotspot has opened its doors to everyone.

The world's first island beach club, Malamala Beach Club, is an Instagram dream with its white sand beaches, crystalline waters, and lush green background.

We're talking lush infinity pools directly overlooking the ocean, swanky cabanas with private butlers to cater to your every whim, stunning coral reefs around the island that are ideal for snorkeling, and of course an a-la-carte menu which has everything from delicious gourmet dishes to pretty spectacular cocktails.

There are also non-motorised watersports on offer from stand up paddle boards to kayaks, for those who like a bit of adventure on their holiday.

The best part? You won't need an A-lister budget to visit. Day passes start from FJ$169, approximately £61. It's not the cheapest day out but considering it's a luxury private island, we're impressed.

(Image: Malamala Beach Club)

Not bad if you want to live out that A-lister lifestyle.

Even luxury extras won't have you breaking the bank; you can hire day beds from FJ$50 (approx £18) for two people, or if you want to treat yourself to a cabana with private butler services, you're looking at rates of FJ$85 per day for two people (approx £30).

(Image: Malamala Beach Club)

The day pass also includes complimentary Wi-Fi, towel service and non-motorised sports equipment. Food and drink however isn't included.

However, even with food and drink on top, it's easily possible to enjoy the full day out, activities and all, for less than £100 each if there are two of you heading on an adventure.

(Image: Malamala Beach Club)

Unfortunately, actually getting there won't be a budget-friendly break for Brits. That's because the beach club is located just off the coast of Fiji, which isn't exactly next door.

Still, if you are planning a trip and want a day of total relaxation, it could be worth leaving a space on the itinerary.

(Image: Malamala Beach Club)

You can find return flights to Fiji from around £958pp on Skyscanner, but you won't find any direct flights; most include a stopover in the USA, normally at Los Angeles.

The total journey time from London takes about 24 hours, but if you're flying from Manchester it can take 26 hours, or from Birmingham it can take 27 hours. (You may want to check out our tips for making long-haul more comfortable if you are taking on the journey).

As for your accommodation? TripAdvisor has a handy round-up of cheap hotels near Port Denarau with prices from £62 per night.

(Image: Malamala Beach Club)

It takes about 25 minutes to reach the island on a high-speed catamaran from Port Denarau (and there are coach pick-ups available from the various resorts nearby).

It's worth noting that Malamala Beach Club isn't available for overnight stays; it's very much a day trip destination.

Ever since it first opened its doors two years ago, the island has proven a hit with visitors - it boasts some pretty great TripAdvisor reviews - and in the last 12 months alone it's welcomed over 34,000 visitors.

You can find out more on the Malamala Beach Club website.
description: Malamala Beach Club is total luxury with infinity pools and butlers but you don't need a big budget to visit
